asteroidsVisitedByAircrafts.name: 1 Ceres
description: Ceres was the first asteroid to be discovered in 1801 by the Italian
astronomer Giuseppe Piazzi. It was at that time considered to be a new planet,
but was later reclassified as an asteroid only to be reclassified again in
2006 as a dwarf planet. Ceres has a diameter approximately
950 km (590 miles), and is thereby the biggest object in the asteroid belt.
The spacecraft Dawn (launched September 27, 2007)
visited Ceres in 2015 after its mission to Vesta.

asteroidsVisitedByAircrafts.name: 4 Vesta
description: Vesta is the second most massive (but not the second largest - Pallas is the second largest by volume)
asteroid in the asteroid belt. It was discovered in 1807 by Heinrich Wilhelm Olbers, and was the fourth asteroid
to be discovered.
Vesta's longest diameter is about 530 km (329 miles), and it has the shape of a
smooshed sphere.
Dawn arrived at Vesta in July 2011.

asteroidsVisitedByAircrafts.name: 21 Lutetia
description: Lutetia was discovered in 1852 by Hermann Mayer Salomon Goldschmidt in France.
It has an irregular shape where the longest diameter is about 132 km, while the smallest
measures about 76 km.
In July 2010, ESA's Rosetta
spacecraft flew by Lutetia on its way to the
comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

asteroidsVisitedByAircrafts.name: 243 Ida
description: 243 Ida was discovered in 1884 by Johann Palisa, an Austrian astronomer, in Vienna.
At the time it was not known that Ida had its own moon. The moon, today known as Dactyl, was not discovered until
100 years later, in 1993, when Ida became the second asteroid to be visited by a spacecraft.
On August 29, 1993 Galileo flew by Ida on its way to Jupiter after it passed
Gaspra two years before.

asteroidsVisitedByAircrafts.name: 253 Mathilde
description: Mathilde was discovered in 1885 by Johann Palisa. Its diameter is about 52 km (32 miles)
and because of its high concentration of carbon, the asteroid is very dark - it reflects
only 4 percent of all incoming light.
In 1997 NEAR
flew by Mathilde on its way to the asteroid 433 Eros.

asteroidsVisitedByAircrafts.name: 433 Eros
description: Eros was discovered in 1898 by both Gustav Witt in Germany and Auguste H.P
Charlois in France (independently of each other). It was the first Near Earth asteroid
to be discovered, and also the first asteroid to be orbited by a spacecraft.
NEAR flew by Eros in December 1998 where it
moved into orbit 2 years after its arrival.
After a year in orbit, the spacecraft finally performed the very first landing on
an asteroid.

asteroidsVisitedByAircrafts.name: 951 Gaspra
description: Gaspra was discovered in 1916 by Grigoriy N. Neujamin. Gaspras largest diameter
is about 20 km (12.5 miles). It was given very little attention until
Galileo's
trajectory was discovered to be close to the asteroid.
In 1991, Galileo flew by Gaspra as the first spacecraft to fly by an asteroid before it later
flew by 243 Ida in 1993 and finally reached Jupiter in 1995.
